Claim: Gender restrictions on nipple showing in the US should be eliminated.
Uncensoring nipples would be beneficial to society as a whole.
Normalising female nudity in society as a whole would put a stop to the hypocrisy inherent in allowing and accepting toplessness in popular and high culture, but not in wider society.
Museums across the globe feature various statues and paintings with true-to-life topless or nude women, even though they are public, family institutions.
Ten of the world's most impactful nude paintings feature women and are on public display in various museums.
The Birth of Venus and La maja desnuda are both depictions of topless women deemed acceptable in popular and high culture.
Some museums implement age restrictions when their exhibitions include nudity or images considered pornographic.
The Sex Machines Museum in Prague does not admit anyone under the age of 18.
Social media sites are currently highly hypocritical with regards to their allowance or censorship of female nipples.

Pornographic or violent images of women’s bodies that appeal to the male gaze are often deemed acceptable by social media, while women who show their own bodies have historically been shamed or censored.
Despite Facebook guidelines against hate speech, many posts promoting or depicting violence against women have been allowed to remain.
Without a qualifying argument, this is as much a reason for the banning of pornographic and violent portrayals of the female body as it is for the uncensoring of female nudity.
Social media sites police female-presenting people's posts and often remove them if nipples are shown, yet posts of art depicting nude figures are typically accepted.
Some social media platforms have changed their policies to allow non-sexualised images of nipples in wider society, such as images of breastfeeding.

Social media sites such as Facebook have allowed airbrushed images of almost nude female celebrities and models to remain whilst simultaneously censoring raw and realistic images of similarly clad women in labour.
While this highlights inconsistencies in social media policies, it doesn't necessarily mean that there should be no restrictions at all.

Anecdotes from many different artists, photographers, and fashion designers around the world suggest that social media sites fairly consistently censor female nipples, even when they form part of an artistic or cultural expression.

After posting a photograph on Facebook of a tribal woman in traditional dress, an award-winning photographer had the post removed since the image was deemed to have breached the site's "community standards".
Facebook and Instagram have been called upon by the National Coalition Against Censorship to relax nipple restrictions for artistic work.
YouTube changed its censorship policies to allow female nipples that it deems are not being depicted in a 'sexualised' manner, thereby uncensoring some artistically-portrayed nipples.

Despite nipple showing being increasingly common in haute couture, this has not become a commercialised fashion trend in the same way that other runway styles have, suggesting that nipple exposure is socially accepted as part of high-end fashion, but not high-street fashion.

It is not hypocritical to allow certain material to be depicted in art, entertainment, and in popular and high culture but not in wider society. Many themes such as sexual assault, violence, and drug-taking are explored through such mediums, yet it is nonetheless understood that these are unacceptable behaviours in the real world.
Some museums include depictions of pornographic behaviors, which, while legal, are considered unacceptable in most liberal democracies but are broadly accepted when depicted as a form of art.

Acts such as murder and rape are not acceptable in society as they inflict clear, unequivocal harm. In contrast, any perceived harm inflicted by female toplessness is entirely subjective and socially constructed.
In many cases, censorship of the female nipple does exist in art and popular culture.
Most countries allow nudity in magazines, but have many restrictions on where and how such magazines are displayed and sold to prevent younger members of the public accessing them.
Although most visual art is protected under the First Amendment, objections often arise when considering works involving nude content.
Some TV stations censor nude artwork and some do not or do it to a lesser extent, highlighting that rules are arbitrary and ineffective.

The majority of nipple censorship in art and popular culture tends only to be done when said art is advertised on social media to the general public, rather than in museums, galleries, and artistic publications or productions.
An Australian art periodical covered the nipples of a nude, pregnant woman painted by the artist Yuskavage.
Censoring only female nipples contributes to gender inequality (p. 430), which causes social harm for all.

Restricting nipple-showing for female-presenting individuals and not others undermines the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which asserts the equal rights and freedoms of all regardless of sex, gender, or any other characteristic.
According to Kant's Formula of Humanity, when a rational being is objectified and deprived of the freedom to make autonomous choices, their humanity and dignity are violated (pp. 6-7).
Human dignity and freedom are also cornerstones of the UDHR. Since female nipple-showing may violate the right to human dignity and freedom, censoring female nipples may in fact uphold the UDHR.

According to Rawls' theory of justice, the banning of female nipples - and thus the curtailing of female freedom – can be justified where it is deemed that their exposure would jeopardise public order and, in turn, the freedoms of everyone (p. 4).
Censoring female nipples may contribute to the perpetuation of gendered stereotypes, which are harmful on both sides of the gender binary.
A WHO study of 41 European countries has shown that men’s health is worse in countries with lower levels of gender equality.
This does not necessitate lifting restrictions on female: gender equality could just as easily be achieved by placing restrictions on all public nipple-showing.
Uncensoring the female nipple will spark greater awareness and understanding of the physical body from a young age, which is beneficial to healthy childhood development.
Children are more likely to display normal, non-intrusive sexual behaviours when raised in social environments that accept nudity and do not enforce physical privacy and modesty.
Uncensoring nipples is likely to trigger earlier adult-to-child education on the non-sexual, biological function of breasts.
Children who are taught about the non-sexual, biological function of breasts by a mature adult are arguably less likely to objectify, shame, or be ashamed of breasts and nipples later in life.
Overemphasis on the biological function of breasts could be considered reductive and inaccurate, since it ignores the idea that breasts can equally - and sometimes only – serve a sexual purpose.
Teaching a child to respect and love their body can be done without promoting the liberation of a woman's body part.

Everyday parenting practices such as avoiding the use of moralising language surrounding food and bodyweight, focusing on mental rather than physical attributes, and demonstrating a healthy relationship with food, exercise, and body image can make significantly positive impacts on a child's view of their body.
Sudden transitions from one status quo to another can elicit collective cultural shock (p. 3), which may cause social backlash and resistance.
Even in seemingly forward thinking communities, topless female-presenting bodies are still considered shocking.
It is not a given that permitting nipple exposure would lead to a significantly greater amount of nipple showing in public.
In countries where restrictions do not exist, toplessness is neither expected nor universally practised: some women decide to go topless in public, while others choose not to do it at all.
Uncensoring nipples may de-sexualize them, which could be detrimental to all those for whom female sexuality is useful or beneficial.
Sexual desire is important in sustaining romantic relationships since it promotes sexual intimacy, which in turn helps to build better bonds and stability between two people.
Removing restrictions on exposing nipples could be harmful to those who work in the sex industry, since many sex workers may rely on the sexualization of breasts to make money.

Research and historical anecdotes both indicate that sex workers with larger breasts often make more money. Insofar as this shows the power of the sexualisation of breasts, if breasts are desexualised via the uncensoring of nipples, this could have a negative impact on the earnings of sex workers.
In Colombia, interviews with sex workers suggest that many see breasts as a "competitive weapon", implying that they use the sexualisation of breasts to maximise their earning potential.

Experienced sex workers opine that their clients have a wide variety of physical preferences, suggesting that financial success in this industry does not rely on the sexualisation of breasts or nipples in particular.
Seeing, but not being able to touch, exposed breasts in public may lead to increased sexual anticipation and desirability surrounding the female nipple.
According to the forbidden fruit effect, when humans are not allowed to access something that is off-limits, their desire for it increases.
Most psychoanalytic models and theories regard desire and satisfaction as linked to fantasy and anticipatory imagination, both of which are reduced in a context where public toplessness is the norm.

A stimulus provokes a lesser emotional response with repeated exposure. Thus, repeatedly seeing women's breasts and nipples in public has the potential to reduce others' biological response to them as sexual stimuli.
The sexual response is built on anticipation, which spikes a person's dopamine levels. Overexposure to eroticized features may decrease anticipation and the corresponding dopamine spike.
Eliminating nipple restrictions has the potential to "re-sexualize" breasts, since it brings all the attention straight towards a woman's chest.

Given historical precedents, it seems likely that the uncensoring of the female nipple would simply lead to other body parts being eroticised to compensate, or else that the female nipple would continue to be arousing only in specific, deliberately sexual contexts.
Some people find hands sexually attractive in particular contexts; the female nipple may emulate this path and have context-bound sexualisation.
The mini skirt originally caused great scandal when introduced, but is now normal in society. People are still able to find legs attractive despite this.
Censoring nipples is oppressive to those who identify as women and those assigned female at birth.
Due to nipple censoring, people are often discriminated against for breastfeeding in public, which can have negative secondary effects.
People can be deterred from breastfeeding due to feeling marginalised or shamed in public. As such, nipple censoring may negatively impact both infant and maternal health.
People are often forced to breastfeed infants or express their milk in unsanitary conditions, such as in public bathroom stalls, because of stigma and a lack of suitable facilities elsewhere.

A survey found that a third of breastfeeding parents pumped milk in unsanitary or otherwise unsuitable conditions at work due to inadequate facilities, leading to 30% of these parents stopping earlier than they would have otherwise done.
There are apps to show nursing parents clean, quiet, and safe places to breastfeed where they will not face negative feedback.
Mamava, Pumpspotting, Feed Finder, and Moms Pump Here are examples of free smartphone apps that act as locators of safe public spaces in which to breastfeed.

Using "solutionist technology" rather than radically solving the root cause of the problem - negative societal attitudes towards breastfeeding - is a conservative approach that ultimately preserves the current problematic system instead of reforming it.
Apps are not accessible for all those who breastfeed.
Many women might not be able to afford a smartphone, with single mothers particularly at risk of living in poverty.

A significantly larger percentage of those living in urban or suburban areas own a smartphone than those living in rural areas, meaning these apps aren't as likely to provide safe breastfeeding environments for rural women.
Statistics show that the disparity between smartphone ownership in urban, suburban, and rural areas in the US is steadily reducing.
Underfeeding can cause unnecessary health issues for a baby, which could be an issue in breastfed babies who refuse to feed from a bottle.
If underfed, some evidence suggests that babies may develop a variety of health conditions that can lead to brain injury.
A study on babies admitted to hospital due to not getting enough breastmilk showed that the infants very rarely had any long-term health issues as a result.
There are many health benefits associated with breastfeeding as compared to infant formula.
Breastfeeding has been shown to reduce incidences of post-partum depression, which is the moderate to severe depression a woman can experience after giving birth.
The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends breastfeeding because it is easier for babies to digest and provides complete nutrition.
Breastfeeding has been linked with a lower risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS).
This could be avoided through pumping breast milk in advance to then feed one's baby from a bottle.
Whether obtained directly from the breast or pumped and fed from a bottle, breastmilk provides perfect infant nutrition and immunity boosting properties.
Many of the health benefits associated with breastfeeding may be lost if fresh breastmilk is not obtained directly by the baby at the breast.

Bottle feeding may require the purchase of bottles, breast pumps, measuring devices, sterilised water, and/or formula, as well as a method of washing and sterilising each item after use. This may cause avoidable strain on both time and finances.
Parents can also be shamed for bottle feeding and using formula when feeding their babies in public. If nipples were uncensored, shaming surrounding bottlefeeding and formula might increase.
Parents can simply cover themselves and/or their babies while nursing to avoid embarrassment or judgement from others in public.
Using a breastfeeding cover can lead to dangerously hot conditions and life threatening breathing difficulties in infants.
Not all babies will feed under a nursing cover.
There are many other reasons parents may be deterred from breastfeeding, all of which could have the same parental and infant health implications.
Many countries have made legal allowances for breastfeeding in public, suggesting that it is unnecessary to uncensor nipples in order for this to be a protected and accepted activity.
All US states have laws that allow breastfeeding in any public or private location.
In the UK, the right to breastfeed in public is protected by law.
In the Philippines, breastfeeding in public is allowed, and breastfeeding mothers are protected by the Expanded Breastfeeding Promotion Act.
The Australian Human Rights Commission has confirmed the right to breastfeed in public.
After a member of Parliament could not combine her breastfeeding schedule with parliamentary duties, Australia’s lower house and Senate implemented a policy allowing breastfeeding on the floor.
There are still reports of people in positions of power shaming breastfeeding mothers or asking them to relocate to a private space in countries where public breastfeeding is legally protected.
Censoring nipples promotes the idea that to show them would be criminal. This encourages the unfair prosecution and shaming of female-presenting bodies.
Women's bodies are constantly policed and shamed for how they look. This should not be extended by banning the showing of body parts solely on the basis of gender.

Society already imposes sexist, contradictory standards on women: they can be slut-shamed for dressing provocatively or acting in a way that is deemed too sexual, yet also criticised for being prudish and not sexual enough.

Restrictions to liberty are justified when something is a threat to public order or security. Since the exposure of female-presenting nipples in public and in the media does not jeopardise the social order, their censorship is unjustified.

Given that female nipples are censored, revealing them in public is classed as public indecency. Since activities much more potentially harmful to public order and safety - such as having sex in public - are categorised in the same way, female nipple showing is loaded with unfair criminal stigma by association.

Unrealistic beauty standards placed on female-presenting bodies by the media mean that many would be subjected to equal - or worse - levels of discrimination and judgment if their nipples were uncensored.

If nipples are uncensored, those who go topless are likely to be those whose nipples already happen to fit the narrow standard currently shown in popular culture and the media. This could work to exacerbate current harmful beauty ideals rather than unravelling them.
Exposure of nipples in Hollywood tends to only show those that are deemed acceptable and visually pleasing.
Increasingly, these narrow beauty standards are being publicly challenged by well-known figures in popular culture, so they are unlikely to last.
According to a Dove social media study, 82 percent of women feel that the standards of beauty set by social media are 'unrealistic'.
This is an argument in favour of challenging unrealistic beauty standards so as to solve the root problem, rather than simply continuing to censor nipples.

Many women already worry about whether the size, shape, and colour of their nipples fit into what is considered "normal" by society, suggesting that harmful beauty ideals surrounding nipples are already rampant. Uncensoring them would be the easiest way to correct this.
Uncensoring female nipples may promote body positivity - which is highly beneficial to physical and mental wellbeing - throughout society.

Studies have shown that exposure to edited and curated photos of celebrities and influencers online can be incredibly harmful to body image. Exposing society to the diversity of 'real-life' bodies via public nipple-showing may counteract this effect.
A 2017 study indicates that being able to see other people's uncovered bodies has a significant positive effect on one's own body image (p. 677).

The concept of body positivity has its roots in the Fat Rights Movement and the celebration of the most marginalised bodies within society. The influence of uncensoring nipples on these causes is likely to be negligible.
Censoring nipples can have negative health implications for those who are female-presenting or who have visibly female breasts/nipples.
Censoring nipples has led to a lack of nipple education, meaning many women either miss or catastrophise possible health problems relating to the nipple.
Many women are either unnecessarily panicked or confused about many benign health issues relating to the nipples simply because they have not been made aware of them before.
Many organisations have found effective ways to raise awareness and educate the public without showing female nipples.
A breast cancer organization in Argentina used a man's chest to teach the public how to check breasts for early cancer detection.

While it is possible to work around censorship policies, it remains more accurate and thus more effective to use female anatomy when disseminating educational messages surrounding health issues that disproportionately affect biologically female people.
Social media nipple restrictions have been criticised for stifling the conversation surrounding women's health choices and female empowerment during labour and childbirth.

Many breast cancer survivors feel their post-mastectomy bodies are stigmatized. Normalizing female-presenting people showing their chests publicly would likely raise awareness and reduce the stigma by showcasing a more diverse range of bodies than what is encompassed by traditional beauty norms.
Breast cancer survivors often have photos of their post-mastectomy bodies censored by social media sites.
Censoring cancer survivors - who use these images to improve their body image and empower themselves - sends a message that their bodies are wrong or unlawful, which can cause psychological harm.
Even if public stigma surrounding breast cancer and mastectomy is reduced, some survivors may feel unable to expose themselves in public due to lingering self-stigma (p. 146).
In restricting posts containing nipples, social media companies have in fact further fuelled the coverage and discussion of this issue in traditional media.
Nipple censorship often requires people to wear a bra, to prevent their nipples from being visible through clothing. Bras are detrimental to the health of some people.
According to some research, wearing a bra can cause increased sweating and irritation, the weakening of certain muscles, and reduced blood circulation in the midsection and ribcage.
For those with larger breasts, bras offer essential support during physical activity that could otherwise lead to poor posture and chronic back, neck, and shoulder pain (p. 1).
Censoring female nipples can be harmful to the mental health of those who identify, or else are labelled, as female.

Gender-based nipple restrictions often misgender transgender and genderfluid people whose breast tissue or general physical appearance is labelled as belonging to a gender that they do not identify with, which can be harmful to their mental health.

Transgender women have voiced their confusion and feelings of conflict at knowing that their nipples are rarely censored by social media unless they undergo gender affirming surgeries, despite them identifying as women long before any surgical procedure they may have.

A transgender woman posting pictures of her chest on social media - to see if she would be considered "female enough" for the posts to be removed - found that her nipples were predominantly left uncensored, even when reported to social media platforms for breaching their female nudity policies.

Restricting nipple showing only further reinforces society's sexualization of the female form, something that is widely acknowledged to be detrimental to the mental health of female-presenting people.

Societal sexualisation of the female form fuels its excessive objectification, which research has shown leads to those with female-presenting bodies feeling shame, anxiety, embarrassment, and body dissatisfaction.
Gender-based nipple restrictions have been a feature in society for many years and across much of history. As such, they are unlikely to be a major contributor to mental health issues.

Across a number of cultures, modesty concerns form a common barrier to female-presenting people accessing healthcare. The primary focus should thus be on designing treatments and health campaigns that work with extant modesty norms (p. 443).

Researchers note that modesty and privacy concerns are some of the key barriers to Muslim women accessing healthcare, but healthcare professionals can significantly improve access by raising awareness of such obstacles and developing strategies to accommodate their preferences while caring for them.
While it will always be important to make reasonable adjustments in healthcare for those who prefer modesty, doing so need not come at the expense of those whose health is harmed by censorship.
The most marginalised women in society are often left unrepresented and alienated by the 'Free The Nipple' movement.

Black women's bodies are particularly hypersexualised (p. 8) yet brutalised by law enforcement (p. 41, pp. 43-44). The current 'Free The Nipple' movement fails to acknowledge this racial disparity and therefore to be as accessible, safe, and empowering for Black women to participate in (p. 11).
The feminist group Femen have been criticised for staging pro-nipple showing protests that used Islamophobic imagery and language.
It is better to have an imperfect movement that liberates some women than to have no movement and thus no change to the liberation of women at all.
Uncensoring nipples may create a trend and expectation for female-presenting people to show their nipples in public, which may feel oppressive to some.

If nipple exposure became mainstream, female-presenting people could feel pressured into exposing their nipples so as to avoid the negative social sanctions associated with non-conformity, even if this would go against their personal beliefs.

This study found that 70% of women were dissatisfied with their own breasts. This suggests that many female-presenting people would feel uncomfortable should nipple-showing become a social expectation.
For some, dressing modestly makes them feel liberated from the objectifying male gaze, so to uncover themselves would feel oppressive.
A societal shift towards uncovering female-presenting bodies may encourage the shaming of those whose religion or culture preaches modesty.

Removing restrictions on nipple showing does not prevent women from dressing modestly. Conversely, however, keeping restrictions in place prevents women who would find nipple-showing liberating from going topless.

In most modern, developed countries, where female-presenting people dress in a variety of styles - some of which can be revealing - individuals are not prevented from dressing modestly if they choose to do so.
The 'Free The Nipple' movement, according to its founder, is about female-presenting people having the choice, rather than idealising the notion of everyone being topless.
Uncensoring nipples could fuel the current pattern of coercing women of colour who prefer to dress modestly into wearing less.

The 'Free The Nipple' campaign centers itself on the idea that bearing one's chest is a form of feminist liberation. Uncensoring nipples may therefore encourage the inaccurate idea that covering up is necessarily a form of sexist oppression.
Restricting nipple showing protects female-presenting people from unwanted sexual harassment.
Female-presenting nipples are more sexualised than male-presenting ones, so are more vulnerable to being the objects of unwanted sexual harassment.

Men have a heightened response to visual sexual stimuli. As long as female nipples continue to be considered sexual stimuli, restricting their exposure is thus a protective measure against inevitable biological responses in men.

A brain-scan study indicated that when heterosexual men are shown photos of scantily clad women, the region of the brain associated with tool use is activated. This suggests that, the fewer clothes women wear, the more likely heterosexual men are to entirely objectify them at the cognitive level.

A correlation between sexism and objectification does not imply an instinctive characteristic: sexism is socially taught, which suggests that the male response to the female form is not biologically innate, and thus can be changed.
If this were the case, it would follow that men's nipples should also be censored as a protective measure against inevitable biological responses in homosexual men.
Studies indicate that homosexual men may value physical appearance more than heterosexual men, and find upper-body muscularity highly desirable (p. 2).
Female hormones cause enlarged breast tissue in anatomically female people. Since breast tissue is sexualised, this has led to a sexualisation-by-association of the female nipple.
Neuroscientists studying sexual internet searches found that breasts were the most popular body part in all the countries they looked at, which supports that female nipples are a sexual trigger.

The nubility hypothesis proposes that since the majority of female breast tissue is not used to produce milk, it evolved solely to function as a sexual signal of reproductive value to men. This supports that breast tissue is sexually attractive to men at a biological level.
Men often have enlarged breast tissue due to either gynecomastia or obesity, yet their nipples remain uncensored.
A photo of a cisgender man with gynecomastia was censored by Spanish media.
Enlarged breast tissue in men has not evolved so as to be sexually appealing, hence why their nipples are uncensored.
At some 'Free The Nipple' public protests, topless female-presenting people have found themselves objectified and sexualised by men.
Dozens of women protesting topless in Argentina were joined by many "male gawkers".

Protests - even if they included male gawkers - raised awareness about the issue in Argentina and propelled actual change: a judge ruled that laws regarding public indecency were unconstitutional and should be overturned.

The weight of the political point being made by these topless protests - which followed an incident where up to 20 police had threatened to arrest 3 women for sunbathing topless at a beach - arguably outweighed the risk of them becoming an objectified spectacle to some onlookers.
Protesters at a 'Free The Nipple' event in New York were outnumbered by spectators and members of the press taking photographs.
Close up, it is often very difficult to identify whether a nipple is male or female.
Instagram removed an image of a perceived female nipple that was later revealed to be a male nipple, proving that male and female nipples are often indistinguishable.

While the core of the issue is indeed specific to the nipple, the taboo nature of a particular nipple is established based on whether it is attached to a male chest or a female breast. As such, 'unattached', genderless nipples viewed in isolation of their owner's chest are somewhat irrelevant.

The sexualisation of certain body parts, including the female breast and nipple, is socially constructed. This suggests that it is wholly possible to alter and decrease the sexualisation of these body parts

There is evidence that, in many cultures that now see exposed nipples as sexual taboo, it was once acceptable or even preferable to show them in public for non-sexual reasons. This suggests that the currently sexual connotations of nipple exposure are entirely culturally determined.
In the Tudor era, it was fashionable for ladies of a higher social class to show one breast, both in court and in portraiture (pp. 44-45).
Exposed breasts were also seen as a way to express one's maiden status and, when depicted in images, to portray a woman as motherly (p. 44).
There were campaigners in Tudor times who expressed disapproval at clothing that exposed female nipples on grounds of this being a display of sexual availability (p. 90).
Toplessness was customary in many cultures until the rise of monotheistic religion, which has often been used for social control (p. 336).
In traditional societies in North America, Africa, Australia, the Pacific Islands, and various parts of Asia, toplessness was customary until the expansion of Christianity and Islam.
In China, the taboo nature of public nudity is rooted in an ancient tradition of Confucian rectitude.
From the late 19th century to the middle of the 20th century, it was common for some Korean women to wear a breast-exposing Hanbok (or breast-exposing Jeogori) in public.
The various artistic impressions of breasts throughout history that suggest nipple exposure was once an accepted norm in Western society are largely thought to be exaggerations.

Research suggests that the media's hypersexualisation of female-presenting bodies heavily influences the corresponding sexualisation of female-presenting people by society, inferring therein that without the media's cultural influence, this sexualisation may not exist.
A 1951 study of 191 cultures found that breasts were considered sexually important to men in only 13 of the cultures.
Cultural anthropologists found that men in Mali were “bemused or horrified” at the perspective of sexual foreplay involving breasts.
In some indigenous communities in Africa, for example, women are often publically bare-chested and their breasts are not considered sexual.
Biologically female nipples are considered erogenous zones, since their stimulation creates a similar neurological and hormonal response to other forms of sexual stimulation.

This study found that in 301 subjects, 82% of women but only 52% of men found stimulation of nipples/breasts to increase arousal, pointing to nipples being biologically more important to female sexuality.
An individual enjoying a particular part of their body being touched doesn't necessarily indicate that it is harmful for others to see that part of their body.
Some women can orgasm with only breast stimulation.
There is anecdotal evidence of men also reaching orgasm through nipple stimulation alone.
There are other erogenous zones on the human body, such as the lips, neck, earlobes, sacrum, abdomen, feet, and navel. None of these body parts are censored.

Men have a relatively higher concentration of nerve endings in the soles of their feet than women do, so pressing on the acupressure points in men's feet can facilitate sexual arousal. By this logic, men's feet should be censored.
The location and daily use of lips makes the possibility of their nationwide censorship too impractical to be compared to the censorship of nipples.
Since stimulation of male nipples can activate the same parts of the brain as stimulation of female nipples, they should not be considered any less erogenous or sexual.
Oxytocin - a hormone released during sexual stimulation - is intrinsically linked to many other physiological processes (p. 8). This suggests it is not purely a response to sexual stimuli.

The release of oxytocin from nipple stimulation is also intended to facilitate flow to breastmilk from the milk glands to the nipple, and to increase the bond between mother and baby, and so is not purely for sexual arousal (p. 11).
Men's breasts are no less sexualized than women's: many women are aroused by a man's pectoral muscles.
Given a parity of sexualisation, visible female presenting nipples may be more likely to solicit unwanted sexual harassment due to the relative social status of men and women.

If restrictions on nipple showing are eliminated for female-presenting people, this could lead to a corresponding elimination of the sociolegal rights and protections currently afforded to their chest and nipples in the event of a sexual assault.
Nipple-showing may exacerbate victim-blaming in cases of sexual harassment and assault against women.

Society is more likely to place partial or full responsibility on female victims for their own assaults if they were dressed in a way that could be considered 'provocative' at the time of their assault.
According to an Amnesty International survey, 26% of UK-based respondents believed that a woman is partially or totally responsible for being raped if she dresses provocatively.
Over half of all male respondents to a 2019 UK-based survey agreed that women who wear more revealing clothes are more likely to be sexually harassed or assaulted.

A woman's clothing is often used as evidence in court trials. This implies that, from a legal standpoint, what a victim was wearing is seen as a possible contributing factor to their own sexual assault.

One judge once remarked that, while she thought it shouldn't be the case, men who sexually attack women are more inclined to take advantage of those who are more vulnerable, such as those wearing more provocative clothing.

Charities and researchers in the field are campaigning for new judiciary guidelines that limit the use of a victim's clothing as evidence against their sexual assault (p. 392), indicating that it may soon cease to be a common practice in court trials.

Victim-blaming in cases of sexual assault is now usually widely condemned where it is identified in institutionalised settings. As such, nipple-showing would likely have little effect on this renounced phenomenon.
The Egyptian media defended a victim of mob sexual assault, who was said by a Salafi preacher to be partially at fault due to her 'provocative' dress.
When the Pakistani Prime Minister implied that victim indecency was the cause of a surge in rape cases, this was met with widespread criticism.

While victim-blaming does tend to be denounced where it is publicly identified, research indicates that it is a highly common phenomenon, such that the total proportion of cases where victims were blamed but then rebolstered by public outcry is likely very small, and so the problem still persists.
That isn't an argument for keeping female nipples censored, but rather for changing socially constructed views so that the phenomenon of victim-blaming based on bodily exposure ceases to exist.
In France, where topless sunbathing is relatively common, conviction rates for verbal, physical, and sexual offences at the beach are low.

Other parts of female-presenting bodies with the potential to be sexualised when exposed - such as lips, hips, and legs – are uncensored, yet they are no less legally protected in cases of sexual harassment.
A man was charged with sexual assault when he repeatedly rubbed the legs of a woman without her consent.
It is unlikely that nipple norms will have much impact on sexual assault investigations because these investigations are rarely conducted, prosecuted, or enforced despite censorship.
Statistics indicate that, in the US, the majority of rape allegations are not properly investigated by the authorities.
The definition of sexual assault also includes the inappropriate, non-consensual touching of male-presenting people, whose nipples are not censored.

According to the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), sexual harassment can include sexual comments, unwelcome sexual advancements, or offensive remarks made by or about anyone of any sex or gender.
Limiting the freedoms of women in the name of their protection is an example of benevolent sexism, which is net harmful towards women (p. 4).
Women showing their breasts and nipples are fully capable of judging the risks of receiving unwanted attention and consequently addressing such attention on their own.
Benevolent sexism has been shown to have a negative impact on women's well-being and career success.
Studies show that many women endorse benevolent sexism as a protective force against hostile sexism.
Restricting nipple showing is ineffective against sexual harassment. There are many more effective ways to protect women from unwanted sexual harassment.

Research suggests that sexual harassment training programmes in the workplace can increase the ability of employees, particularly men, to identify sexually harassing behaviour. This could work to reduce the incidence of such behaviour in society as a whole.
Research suggests that sexual harassment training may actually make men less capable of noticing when inappropriate behaviour occurs.
Educating schoolchildren about consent and rape culture would be much more effective in solving the root causes of harassment and assault against female-presenting people.

Recent surveys indicate that less than a third of US adults were educated on sexual consent or assault while at school, and even fewer were taught how to ask for sexual consent. This indicates a lack of vital early education on these issues.

Since children can adapt to new ways of thinking more easily than adults, challenging and changing problematic views surrounding consent and rape from a young age would likely be key in drastically reducing the number of adults who commit or fall prey to sexual assault and harassment.

Programmes around the world that have been designed to educate school-age boys and young men on issues of sexual harassment have all been proven to increase recognition of abusive behaviour and reduce instances of sexual violence perpetration.

After completing an educational programme surrounding rape culture in Kenya, it was found that schoolboys were significantly more likely to intervene if witnessing sexual assault and less likely to hold inaccurate views of rape, while schoolgirls reported far fewer rapes.

Some teachers note that schoolchildren are often apathetic to attempts to change problematic views they have on rape culture, suggesting they may lack the maturity required to be effectively educated on such issues at such a young age.

There is no evidence that what victims of sexual assault were wearing at the time of their assault had any bearing on its occurrence, suggesting that the censorship of women's nipples is irrelevant in this context.
Statistics suggest that sexual violence against women is often more prevalent in countries where women are more likely to wear more conservative clothing.
South Africa, a sexually conservative country, has the highest occurrence of rape in the world.
In Middle Eastern and South Asian societies, where many women are expected to dress extremely conservatively, cases of rape, sexual assault, and sexual harassment against women are high.
99.3% of all Egyptian women have experienced some form of sexual assault.
Nearly 80% of women in India have experienced sexual harassment or assault in the street.
Many countries that are considered liberal have high rates of rape and other sexual assaults.
Sweden and Denmark, both countries known to be 'sexually liberal', have the highest number of sexual assaults in Europe.
Sweden's high rate of rape is largely due to the fact that they have redefined the definition of the crime to include acts that many other places in the world do not consider as rape.
The US, which is considered a very liberal country, has a comparatively high occurrence of rape and sexual assault.
A nationwide 2019 study in the US found that 81% of women had experienced sexual harassment at some point in their lifetime.
American women and girls still experience sexual violence at high rates: 1 out of every 6 American women has been the victim of an attempted or completed rape in her lifetime.

Sexual assault may be less reported to law enforcement agencies in conservative countries than in liberal countries (p. 245). Since sexual assault statistics are generally gathered from such agencies, it is therefore likely that reported figures in more conservative countries are an inaccurate reflection of actual sexual assault rates.

In Saudi Arabia, there is no specific law criminalising rape, and female victims may themselves be incriminated if they were seen to be violating purdah during their encounter with the perpetrator. This may discourage victims from reporting cases of sexual assault.

Seven out of the ten countries with the highest rate of violence against women in the world are in Latin America, where human trafficking and organized crime seem to play a more significant role than dress.

Since there is no contemporary precedent for a culture in which laws have changed from censoring to uncensoring female, it is impossible to say with certainty that restricting nipple showing is ineffective against sexual harassment.
If restricting nipple showing has any mitigating influence on sexual harassment at all, it makes sense to keep it alongside other strategies, even if other strategies are more effective.

A study carried out in Egypt found that, in 54.5% of cases, the focus of sexual harassment is a woman's breasts (p. 11). This suggests that nipple showing may exacerbate sexual harassment against female-presenting people, even if it is not the root cause.
Many female-presenting people believe that taking steps to cover up bodyparts, for example by wearing a hijab or veil, does have some protective effects against sexual harassment.

Continuing to enforce nipple censorship laws on grounds of their minimally protective effects against sexual harassment could lead to institutional complacency, and thus a lack of drive to implement other more effective solutions.
The public display of female nipples runs counter to the virtue of modesty taught by many cultures and religions practised in the US.
Traditionally, Jewish faith and culture - with which an estimated 5.3 million Americans identify - emphasises modesty in all clothing choices.
Women in Haredi communities often follow a strict dress code in order to adhere to Jewish laws on modesty.
Progressive Judaism rejects literal interpretations of Jewish law and the Bible, verses from which form the basis of the religion's modesty culture.
While also having public spaces that cater to its more traditional Jewish inhabitants, Israel also has a number of nudist beaches and festivals.
The Jewish community is culturally diverse: not all Jews identify as religious, and many have highly liberal values.
Female followers of Islam, which has around 3.45 million followers in the US, are expected to be modest in the way they dress and act.
In Islam, women are encouraged to wear a headscarf as a form of hijab in order to show modesty.
In Islam, men and women should only view each other's naked bodies in the context of Nikah (marriage).

In the Quran, the practice of modesty is asked of men first, through the 'modest' lowering of their gaze. Islam may thus place greater importance on modest male behaviour than on the modest clothing choices of women.
Increasingly, Muslim women are choosing not to subscribe to this expectation.
Christianity, a religion followed by 65% of Americans, considers nudity outside of sexual contexts to be sinful.
Some interpretations consider that nudity mainly appears in the Bible in sinful contexts, therefore Christians should not be nude in public.

Nudity in the Bible is only explicitly condemned when it is associated with a sinful act, breach of personal autonomy, or lack of basic clothing due to poverty. This suggests Christianity accepts nudity in other contexts.
Evidence suggests that baptisms were performed naked in the early Christian church.
It is unclear whether 'naked' baptisms would have meant that all clothing was removed, or that such baptisms would have been performed on women as well as men.
Christian naturist groups exist and believe the practice is compatible with their religious beliefs and with scriptural teachings.
Many countries with similar cultural values to the US permit female toplessness.
In Canada, it is legal for a woman to be topless in public without any covering, provided that the act of being topless is not intentionally indecent.
Alberta lifted restrictions on nipple coverings for performers in 2015.
In 2017 a woman filed a complaint with the Human Rights Tribunal in Ontario because she was not allowed to swim topless.
Germany has a relaxed attitude towards nudity.
Germany's culture of nudity and body expression, Freikörperkultur, is uniquely German.
It is not illegal for a woman to go topless in the UK, provided that she does not do so in a way that is considered 'disorderly'.
Individuals whose intention is to go about their normal business, only nude, are unlikely to be prosecuted.
The US is still predominantly operating under Puritan values, where showing nipples is considered grossly inappropriate.
Puritan settlers in the US took the scriptures more literally than other Christian movements, resulting in a prudish mentality across the whole society.
Even if public nipple exposure clashes with cultural or religious values, it is not a government's place to act on this.
Many countries have secular governments, and so their national laws and policies are not influenced by religious ideologies.
The separation of church and state is an important facet of culture and freedom in the US.
According to a 1981 UN Declaration, all governments have a duty to protect the religious freedoms of their citizens.
While the UN institutes the right to and protections of religious freedom, it also asserts that this only applies insofar as it does not infringe on others' liberties (p. 2).
